flares.note: Occulted flare from behind the W limb as seen from SDO AIA 131. The flare and associated eruption are seen in STEREO A EUV imagery at 2026-01-31T04:49Z, located in former Active Region 4351 (S04W55 as seen from STEREO A).
Peak occurs at 2026-02-02T20:09Z as it wavers ~M2.9 for several minutes.

cmes.note: Streamer blowout CME first seen to the NE by SOHO LASCO C2 beginning at 2026-01-27T01:36Z, as well as by SOHO LASCO C3, STEREO A COR2 and GOES CCOR-1 in later frames. The source of this event is seen in GOES SUVI 284 as wide rising and opening field lines beginning around 2026-01-26T22:42Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on approximate source location and best fit in SOHO LASCO C2/C3, STEREO A COR2 and GOES CCOR-1.

cmes.note: Narrow CME first seen to the West by SOHO LASCO C2 beginning at 2026-01-27T01:48Z, as well as by SOHO LASCO C3 and GOES CCOR-1 in later frames. This CME is not visible in STEREO A COR2 due to a data gap from 2026-01-26T17:08Z to 2026-01-27T03:23Z. The source of this event is a small eruption seen on the Western limb beginning at approximately 2026-01-27T00:29Z. A small amount of material can be seen leaving the disk in SDO AIA 304, along with field line opening visible in SDO AIA 193. This source is not visible in STEREO A EUVI imagery due to the same data gap as COR2A.

cmeAnalyses.note: Plane-of-sky measurement using a longitude of W90 due to source location near the limb and lack of STEREO A COR2 imagery to triangulate. Range of longitude fits between W70 and W120.

cmes.note: CME first seen to the SE by SOHO LASCO C2 beginning at 2026-01-27T10:36Z, as well as by STEREO A COR2 in later frames. The source of this event is a C2.9 class flare from beyond the SE limb which peaked at 2026-01-27T09:43Z. This flare can be seen in SDO AIA 131, along with field line opening and post eruptive arcades seen in SDO AIA 193.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on approximate source location and best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/GOES CCOR-1 and STEREO A COR2. This fit suggests a high Southern deflection.

cmes.note: CME visible to the west in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and GOES CCOR-1. It is also visible to the west in STEREO A COR2 after a real-time data gap from 2026-01-27T15:38Z to 2026-01-28T03:23Z. The potential source may be an eruption with opening field lines beyond the west limb best in SDO AIA 193/GOES SUVI 284 starting at 2026-01-28T23:31Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on potential source location as well as the best fit between SOHO LASCO C3, GOES CCOR-1, and STEREO A COR2 imagery in SWPC_CAT.

cmes.note: CME visible to the west in SOHO LASCO C2/C3, GOES CCOR-1, and STEREO A COR2. The potential source is an eruption seen in STEREO A EUV 195 imagery starting around 2026-01-28T05:55Z, with dimming and opening field lines visible on the disk around S15W90. The eruption is also visible as opening field lines in SDO AIA 171/193 and GOES SUVI 284.

cmeAnalyses.note: Limited imagery was available for this measurement due to the faintness of the leading edge of the CME.

cmes.note: CME visible to the NE in GOES CCOR-1, SOHO LASCO C2/C3, and STEREO A COR2. The source is likely a filament eruption on the east limb as best seen in GOES SUVI 304 imagery, with liftoff starting at 2026-01-28T12:28Z. Opening field lines are also seen in SDO AIA 171/193 and GOES SUVI 284.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on the best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3, GOES CCOR-1, and STEREO A COR2 imagery in SWPC_CAT.
Preliminary measurement based on the potential source location using GOES CCOR-1 imagery in SWPC_CAT.

cmes.note: Very faint CME first seen to the SE in SOHO LASCO C2 starting around 2026-01-28T21:12Z. This front is also faintly seen in GOES CCOR-1, but it is too "fuzzy" to be measurable. There is not good source candidate for this CME on the Earth-facing disk. The source may be far-sided.

cmeAnalyses.note: Plane-of-sky measurement based on running difference imagery from SOHO LASCO C2.

cmes.note: Extremely faint front first seen to the NE part way into the FOV of SOHO LASCO C2 starting at 2026-01-28T21:48Z. This CME is only seen in SOHO LASCO C2 for three frames of running difference imagery. It is also seen to the NE in GOES CCOR-1. The CME is covered by a real-time data gap in STEREO A COR2. It is too faint to discern in white light. There is a small filament eruption from AR 14359 (N20E30) best seen in SDO AIA 171 starting around 2026-01-28T20:30Z that could be related.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on speculative source around AR 14359 (N20E30).

cmes.note: Narrow CME first seen to the NE in SOHO LASCO C2 around 2026-01-28T22:36Z. This CME is also seen to the NE in SOHO LASCO C3 and GOES CCOR-1 but is covered by a real-time data gap in STEREO A COR2. There is no good source candidate on the Earth-facing disk.

cmeAnalyses.note: Plane-of-sky measurement based on running difference imagery from SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and GOES CCOR-1.

cmes.note: Narrow, faint CME first seen to the NNW by SOHO LASCO C2 beginning at 2026-01-29T02:00Z. This CME fades before exiting the field-of-view in SOHO LASCO C2, and is therefore not visible in SOHO LASCO C3 or GOES CCOR-1. This CME is also not visible in STEREO A COR2 due to a data gap from 2026-01-28T15:53Z to 2026-01-29T03:23Z. The source of this event is faint field line opening seen along the NW limb in SDO AIA 193 beginning around 2026-01-29T01:00Z, exhibiting some possible Northern deflection.

cmeAnalyses.note: Plane-of-sky measurement using a longitude of W90 due to faint source near the limb and lack of STEREO A COR2 imagery to triangulate or STEREO A EUVI to observe exact source longitude. Longitudes are fitting between W50 and W130.

cmes.note: CME first seen to the SSE by SOHO LASCO C2 beginning at 2026-01-29T04:12Z, as well as by SOHO LASCO C3, STEREO A COR2 and GOES CCOR-1 in later frames. No source is visible, as source is likely far sided.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on best fit between SOHO LASCO C2 and STEREO A COR2.

cmes.note: CME first seen to the SE by SOHO LASCO C2 beginning at 2026-01-29T08:24Z, as well as by STEREO A COR2 and GOES CCOR-1 in later frames. The source of this event is a minor eruption seen along the SE limb near Active Region 14362 (approx. S20E80) seen beginning around 2026-01-29T07:52Z in SDO AIA 304, with field line opening also seen in SDO AIA 171.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on approximate source location and best fit in SOHO LASCO C2, STEREO A COR2 and GOES CCOR-1.

cmes.note: CME first seen to the SSE by GOES CCOR-1 beginning at 2026-01-29T12:45Z, as well as to the SSW in STEREO A COR2 in later frames. This CME is not visible in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 in real time due to a downlink data gap which began at 2026-01-29T08:24Z. The source of this event is field line opening seen beyond the SE limb in SDO AIA 171 beginning around 2026-01-29T11:10Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on approximate source location and best fit in GOES CCOR-1 and STEREO A COR2.

cmes.note: CME first seen to the NW by GOES CCOR-1 beginning at 2026-01-29T15:00Z, as well as by STEREO A COR2 in later frames. The source of this event is a C1.2 flare and small eruption near former Active Region 14350 (N18W61) which peaked at 2026-01-29T14:31Z. This flare is visible in SDO AIA 131, along with field line opening seen in SDO AIA 171, 193 and 211.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on source location and best fit in GOES CCOR-1 and STEREO A COR2.

cmes.note: Faint, narrow CME seen to the E in SOHO LASCO C2 and GOES CCOR-1 and very faintly in a few early images of C3. Fully covered by the daily data gap in STEREO A COR2. Its source could be a minor prominence off/from just behind the E limb best seen in GOES SUVI 304/284 and also seen in SDO AIA 304/131/193/171 starting 2026-01-29T21:03Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: The CME source is either the E limb or behind the E limb. This CME is fully covered by the daily data gap in STEREO A imagery. Therefore, the only analysis possible is plane-of-sky, using SOHO LASCO and GOES CCOR-1 imagery

cmes.note: Faint CME with a messy partial halo front seen to the SE in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and GOES CCOR-1 but covered by the daily data gap in STEREO A. Its source is likely the movement/opening of field lines behind the SE limb best seen after 2026-01-29T22:40Z in GOES SUVI 284 and also in SDO AIA 171/193.

cmeAnalyses.note: Updated, triangulated measurement based on later frames including STEREO A COR2.

The CME is far-sided, with the behind-the-limb source indicated by movement/opening of field lines seen in EUV imagery. The CME is covered by the daily data gap in STEREO A imagery, so no triangulation is possible. Plane-of-sky analysis is the only analysis available for this event

cmes.note: Narrow, jet-like CME first seen to the NE in SOHO LASCO C2 staring around 2026-01-30T13:26Z. This CME is also seen to the NE in SOHO LASCO C3, GOES CCOR-1, and STEREO A COR2. The source of this narrow, jet-like CME is most likely associated with some field line rising near the NE limb best seen in SDO AIA 193 beginning around 2026-01-30T11:58Z. Some small post-eruptive arcades are also visible around an unnumbered region located around N15E70 in SDO AIA 193 beginning around 2026-01-30T13:00Z. There is some northward deflection evident particularly once the CME reaches the FOV of SOHO LASCO C3.

cmeAnalyses.note: Triangulated measurement based on running difference imagery from SOHO LASCO C2/C3, STEREO A COR2, and GOES CCOR-1 as well as visible source location near the NE limb.

cmes.note: CME observed to the E only in 3 available frames of STEREO A COR2 due to a data gap beginning at 2026-01-30T18:38Z. Not visible in GOES CCOR-1 or SOHO LASCO C2/C3, perhaps too faint or obscured by the occulting disk. No distinct source for this CME is observed on-disk.

cmeAnalyses.note: STEREO A COR2 plane-of-sky at E38.2, with STEREO A's position at W51.8.

cmes.note: Diffuse, faint CME observed to the NE in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and GOES CCOR-1, not in STEREO A COR2 due to a data gap. The source may be filament ejecta just on/beyond the east limb starting around 2026-01-30T23:21Z in SDO AIA 304, deflecting northward.

cmeAnalyses.note: SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and GOES CCOR-1 plane-of-sky, with no STEREO A COR2 to triangulate and a source likely just beyond the east limb with northward deflection.

cmes.note: Fast, asymmetric CME with a front best seen in SOHO LASCO imagery but also clear in running difference imagery in all coronagraphs (SOHO LASCO C2/C3, STEREO A COR2 and GOES CCOR-1). Associated with the occulted C6.0 flare from former Active Region 14351 (S04W107) from behind the W limb in SDO, peaking at 2026-01-31T04:54Z, and an eruption with opening of field lines seen in SDO AIA 193/171 starting 2026-01-31T04:50Z. The flare and eruption are best seen (as dimming, post-eruptive arcades and an EUV wave) in STEREO A EUV 195/304 in the Active Region 14351 (located behind the W limb in SDO, at S04W55 as seen from STEREO A), making the source location coordinates S04W107.

cmeAnalyses.note: Analysis based on the location of the source (C6.0 flare and eruption in the former Active Region 14351, seen in STEREO A EUV imagery after 2026-01-31T04:50Z.

cmes.note: A very faint, minor CME seen to the W in all three coronagraphs (SOHO LASCO C2/C3, STEREO A COR2 and GOES CCOR-1). Source for this event has not been found in EUV imagery.

cmeAnalyses.note: Very approximate, speculative analysis based on the fit with 3 coronagraphs (SOHO LASCO C2/C3, STEREO A COR2 and GOES CCOR-1). No source has been found in EUV imagery to confirm this analysis.

cmes.note: Faint CME with a pointy, dimpled front to the NW in SOHO LASCO C2 and GOES CCOR-1, partially obscured by a pylon in SOHO LASCO C3. The corresponding super faint, messy front is possibly seen to the NE in STEREO A COR2 in a few limited timeframes. The source of this CME could be a very small eruption just E of former AR 14365 (~N28W20), seen in SDO starting at 2026-01-31T13:49Z as minor dimming and small size post-eruptive arcades.

cmeAnalyses.note: Very approximate analysis based on the fit with three coronagraphs (SOHO LASCO C2/C3, STEREO A COR2 and GOES CCOR-1) and confirmed by the location of the possible source, with some minor deflection westwards from the source eruption.

cmes.note: CME first observed to the SW in STEREO A COR2 before a data gap begins at 2026-01-31T19:38Z preventing a good view of front development, then later to the W in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and GOES CCOR-1, starting at 2026-01-31T22:12Z in LASCO C2. With an ongoing SOHO LASCO campaign reducing data quality and the STEREO A COR2 gap, no overlapping observations of the front are possible in real-time, but there is good confidence in this being the same front due to an observed far-sided source and no other on-disk sources at this time. The far-sided source is observed in STEREO A EUVI 304/195 starting around 2026-01-31T16:15Z on the west limb as viewed from STEREO A, putting it around W141.8 with the spacecraft currently at W51.8.

cmeAnalyses.note: SOHO LASCO C2/C3 only plane-of-sky. Considering this analysis true with the speculative nature of the other 3D single spacecraft analysis, due to the factors noted within that analysis entry.

3D single spacecraft analysis with SOHO LASCO C3 and one LASCO C2 frame, using the observed source around W141.8 in STEREO A EUVI imagery as the basis, and the longitude could easily  vary +-10 degrees. Analysis is quite speculative due to LASCO data quality with an ongoing campaign, STEREO A COR2 data gap, and LASCO C2/C3 and GOES CCOR-1 fronts not aligning well with the lemniscate tool.

cmes.note: Faint CME with a diffuse leading edge observed to the NE in SOHO LASCO C2/C3, GOES CCOR-1, and briefly in STEREO A COR2 before a data gap. The source is very likely a C7.0 class flare (N16E56) from AR 14366 peaking at 2026-01-31T18:33Z observed in SDO AIA 131, eruption also observed as field line movement, dimming region centered around N23E58, and surface brightening in SDO AIA 171/193/304.

cmeAnalyses.note: Single spacecraft 3D analysis with limited SOHO LASCO C3 frames due to an ongoing campaign, also due to poor LASCO C2 and STEREO A COR2 image quality and availability. Uses the flare source at N16E56 and dimming source at N23E58 finding some northward deflection, although some variance in the latitude and longitude is expected with the single-spacecraft analysis.

cmes.note: Narrow CME visible to the NE in STEREO A COR2 imagery. It is not clearly seen in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 nor GOES CCOR-1 imagery. There is no clear source for this CME, but it is possibly associated with flaring activity from Active Region 14366 located in the NE of the Earth-facing disk.

cmeAnalyses.note: Plane-of-sky measurement using -38 degrees for longitude based on STEREO A's location at time of CMEs first appearance in STEREO A imagery.

cmes.note: This CME is faintly seen to the NE in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery. There is no clear source for the CME however it is possible it is associated with flaring activity from Active Region 14366 in the NE of the Earth-facing disk.

cmeAnalyses.note: Parameters based on best fit using SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery. This measurement includes a very faint wider front visible in SOHO LASCO C2 frames. The brightest portion of this CME is visible along the southern edge of the CME with a much more narrow appearance. This CME in STEREO A is more clearly defined in difference imagery.

cmes.note: CME first seen to the SE by SOHO LASCO C2 beginning at 2026-02-01T12:48Z, as well as by SOHO LASCO C3, STEREO A COR2 and GOES CCOR-1 in later frames. The source of this event is fast rising loops and opening field lines seen along the SE limb in SDO AIA 171, 193 and GOES SUVI 284 beginning at approx. 2026-02-01T10:53Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on approximate source location and best fit in SOHO LASCO C2/C3, STEREO A COR2 and GOES CCOR-1.

cmes.note: Complex CME consisting of multiple overlapping fronts, the first of which is first seen to the NE in SOHO LASCO C2 beginning at 2026-02-02T00:48Z, as well as in GOES CCOR-1 in later frames. The start of this event is covered in STEREO A COR2 by a data gap which began at 2026-02-01T14:53Z and ended at 2026-02-02T03:23Z, but after the data gap at least one lobe of this CME is clearly seen to the ENE in STEREO A COR2 in multiple timestamps. The source of this event is an X8.1 flare from Active Region 14366 (N13E35) that peaked at 2026-02-01T23:57Z and possibly also the following X2.8 flare from the same AR peaking at 2026-02-02T00:36Z. The flares are visible in SDO AIA and GOES SUVI 131. Two bouts of filament ejecta are also seen in SDO AIA and GOES SUVI 304 in association with these flares, the earlier ejecta more northwardly directed and seemingly deflecting towards the west, and the ejecta after the second flare which is not as northward as the initial one.

cmeAnalyses.note: Final, approximate and speculative analysis based on the fitting with all three coronagraphs (SOHO LASCO C2/C3, STEREO A COR2 and GOES CCOR-1) once STEREO A COR2 imagery became available after the end of the daily data gap in STEREO A. This analysis leaves out the earliest, more northward, faint front seen in SOHO C2 and CCOR-1 as the likely corresponding very faint front in the first couple of available STEREO A COR2 after the data gap is very unclear/obscured by brighter following front. The CME is treated as one event in this analysis. The fitting indicates a likely significant deflection westwards from the source location (location of the X-class flares from Active Region 14366), possibly due to the effect of the coronal hole to the NE of the Active Region location. Analysis is complicated by the asymmetrical shape of the CME in STEREO A COR2, the fact that the start of the CME is obscured by the data gap in STEREO and the difficulty separating multiple overlapping fronts in SOHO and CCOR-1.

Preliminary measurement with one-coronagraph analysis method, using early GOES CCOR-1 frames before SOHO LASCO and STEREO A COR2 imagery became available for this event, based on the approximate source location (X8 flare).

cmes.note: CME/outflow seen to the NE in SOHO LASCO C2/C3, GOES CCOR-1 and (most clearly) in STEREO A COR2 following and overlapping with CME: 2026-02-02T00:48Z. (Its start in LASCO might be somewhat different). This is the most distinct outflow front among the multiple follow ups to CME: 2026-02-02T00:48Z. It is especially distinct in STEREO A COR2, as it seems to have a higher latitude than the CME: 2026-02-02T00:48Z. Its source is not clear but could be the long-duration M5.2 flare from AR 4366 (N13E35) peaking at 2026-02-02T02:51Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Speculative analysis based on the fit of the front in three coronagraphs (SOHO LASCO C2/C3, STEREO A COR2 and GOES CCOR-1). It is not clear which of the multiple fronts in SOHO/CCOR-1 corresponds to the more clear front in STEREO A. The possible source (flare from AR 14366) is more eastward than the longitude we are obtaining from triangulation, so there might be westward deflection of the CME.

cmes.note: Faint narrow CME visible to the NE in SOHO LASCO C2 and STEREO A COR2 imagery. It is not clearly seen in SOHO LASCO C3 and GOES CCOR-1 imagery. The source appears to be an M-class flare from Active Region 14366 in the NE peaking at 2026-02-02T11:24Z as seen in SDO/AIA 131. There is a coronal hole near this Active Region which may have contributed to deflection of the CME.

cmeAnalyses.note: Parameters based on best fit using SOHO LASCO C2 and STEREO A COR2 imagery. There may be some uncertainty with this fit due to the faintness of the CME.

cmes.note: This CME is visible to the SW in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and GOES CCOR-1 imagery. It is not visible in STEREO A COR2 due to a data gap beginning at 2026-02-02T15:23Z. There is no clear source for this CME.

cmeAnalyses.note: Parameters based on plane-of-sky fit of CME feature using the SWPC_CAT measuring tool. There is a fainter wider portion not included in this measurement due to difficulty in seeing it. It is more notable in white-light imagery.
